awd_titl_txt: Eddy-internal wave interactions in regions of frontogenesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Near-inertial waves, mesoscale eddies, and fronts are ubiquitous in the ocean. Classical theory predicts that the interaction between the fast, unbalanced waves and the slow, balanced eddies is usually weak. A new theory demonstrates, however, that this interaction can be strong in regions of frontogenesis, where mesoscale strain drives a cross-front ageostrophic circulation and rapidly intensifies thermal wind shear. This change in geostrophic flow modifies the polarization relation of near-inertial waves that are present, making their horizontal velocity rectilinear, and resulting in a Reynolds stress that draws kinetic energy from the eddies. The kinetic energy transferred from eddies is ultimately lost to the ageostrophic circulation, hence the near-inertial waves play a catalytic role in loss-of-balance. In the process the waves lose all of their energy. Scaling arguments based on a simple theoretical model for the interaction suggest that it could play a significant role in closing the global kinetic energy budgets for both near-inertial waves and eddies. To correctly assess the impact of this process on global energy balances, however, the physics of the mechanism must be understood without the simplifying assumption used in the model of a spatially homogeneous front and wave field. This project aims to do this using a hierarchy of hydrostatic and non-hydrostatic numerical simulations of spatially localized fronts and wave fields. Two dimensional simulations will be performed that are designed to study the modifications of the waves and isolate the wave-induced changes to the mean flow. These will not, however, allow the changes in mean flow to feedback on the wave dynamics. Three-dimensional hydrostatic simulations without this constraint will be used to investigate these feedbacks and quantify the wave-induced adjustments to the eddy kinetic energy. The ultimate fate of the kinetic energy lost from the wave and eddy fields to presumably small-scale turbulence will be investigated with high-resolution non-hydrostatic simulations.

Intellectual Merit: The theory that forms the basis of the proposed research merges studies of frontal dynamics, internal wave physics, and wave mean flow interactions, yielding rich new phenomena that may shed light on one of the fundamental problems in geophysical fluid dynamics of how kinetic energy is transferred from balanced to unbalanced motions and dissipated. At the same time, the work provides a mechanism for the removal of the kinetic energy in the near-inertial wave field, a problem that is not fully understood.

Broader Impacts: The proposed research tackles one of the outstanding questions in physical oceanography ? how the kinetic energy in the mesoscale is dissipated. This is important because how eddies lose their kinetic energy affects their properties, with consequences for the large-scale circulation and hence climate. The research points to a pathway where kinetic energy from eddies and internal waves drives mixing at fronts, with implications for nutrient fluxes, primary productivity, and water mass transformation. Insights from this study will guide the development of parameterizations for the dissipation of eddies and near-inertial waves for use in global circulation models. The project will be used to train a graduate student and includes mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher. The research results will be incorporated into lectures and outreach activities that provoke interest and fascination in the ocean circulation.

por.por_cntn:
In the mid and high latitudes, the ocean is pummeled by storms through much of the year. Storm winds create waves on the sea surface that can propagate to distant shores, break, and in so doing, accelerate currents like rip currents. These winds also generate waves within the ocean known as near-inertial waves (NIWs) which carry vast amounts of energy. When these NIWs break, their energy can fuel turbulent mixing and currents, similar to surface waves crashing on the seashore.  But unlike surface waves, the locations of the surf zones where NIWs break are not well known. This project has identified ocean fronts -- regions of large lateral contrasts in temperature, salinity, and density, such as the Gulf Stream -- as hot spots for NIW breaking. Using analysis of observations, theoretical calculations, and numerical simulations, the conditions under which NIWs lose their energy at fronts have been determined and the implications for mixing and the acceleration of currents explored.

 

Observations from the Gulf Stream collected as part of the LATMIX wintertime field campaign and analyzed as part of this project reveal evidence of NIW breaking on the northern side of the current where there is a strong front. The waves are manifest as bands of shear that tend to run parallel to the sloping density surfaces of the front. The shear of the waves was intense enough to enhance small-scale mixing, indicating that the NIWs were generating turbulence and breaking. Theoretical calculations were used to interpret the observations and suggest that the NIWs become trapped at the front because of its lateral density gradient, resulting in an accumulation of wave energy and wave breaking. This NIW “surf zone” is positioned on the boundary between the subpolar and subtropical gyres and could contribute to mixing temperature, salinity, and nutrients across the gyres.

 

Fronts in the ocean are quite dynamic features and can be intensified by the confluence of currents (such as off Cape Hatteras where the subpolar and subtropical gyres collide and form the Gulf Stream front). This is a process known as frontogenesis, and NIWs caught in these conditions experience dramatic changes in their properties that can lead to wave damping. Numerical simulations performed as part of this project reveal that the damping of the NIWs is asymmetric depending on the direction that waves propagate when approaching a front. If the waves come from the dense side of the front they become trapped and absorbed by the front, transferring their energy to its currents. In contrast, NIWs traveling from the light side of the front are rapidly channeled down at the front and radiate their energy into the ocean abyss. NIWs that are initially stationary are also affected by actively intensifying fronts. Under these conditions, the upwelling and downwelling motions that straddle the fronts distort the NIWs, causing the waves to radiate energy to the deep. This effect is most pronounced for NIWs with short vertical wavelengths, which are typically found at the base of the mixed layer and that are thought to play an important role in deepening the mixed layer through mixing. The results from this project suggest that these NIWs, if coincident with fronts, can lose energy through radiation which would reduce their effectiveness in driving mixing. Fronts are ubiquitous in the upper ocean, so this scenario is likely common, but further study involving observations and theory is required to determine if this is the case. 

 

 

 

Finally, this project also addressed how the reflection of NIWs off the surface or bottom of the ocean are affected by fronts. NIWs, like all internal waves, do not follow Snell’s law of reflection. Namely, the angle of an internal wave’s reflection is not equal to its angle of incidence, but instead depends on its frequency. These angles further depend on the slope of surfaces of constant density, which at fronts are tilted. As a consequence, at fronts NIWs can experience a phenomenon known as critical reflection, where their energy is focused and amplified in a thin layer near the surface upon reflection. This facilitates wave breaking and mixing and ultimately leads to a loss of energy for the waves. Evidence of an analogous phenomenon was observed near the bottom of the ocean in the eastern Equatorial Pacific where measurements of turbulence revealed bottom-intensified mixing over regions of smooth topography. While there are no fronts in these regions, the Earth’s spin direction near the equator modifies the physics of the waves in similar ways to fronts and allows for critical reflection off of smooth topography. The results have implications for the deep branch of the meridional overturning circulation which is thought to be partially driven by mixing in the abyssal waters of the Equatorial Pacific Ocean.
